title: Why are we finding stars older than the universe? How can we be finding them so close to our galaxy, like the Methuselah star? - Quora

response.answer_text: We aren’t. The so-called “Methuselah star” is a very old star. Recently, some astronomers performed a computation from observational data on the star and came up with a range of possible ages. If the star is as old as the oldest age in the range, then it’s older than the estimated age of the universe. But, if it’s close to the age of the most likely age in the range, then it’s just a first generation star. Nothing surprising about it. Sure. It’s a bit amusing that the formulas give a possible age older than the universe, but it’s not actually meaningful. There’s simply no reason to think that interpretation is true.
